I think Cisco Fabric Services are an excellent suggestion. CFS keeps SAN fabrics consistent. As data center networks become more tightly coupled, these tools are needed.

In the mean time, while by no means perfect, Putty Connection Manager or 'screen' helps with issuing commands to multiple hosts at the same time.

comments.html:
Ivan,

I agree with the original complaint - that consistency checker takes out VPCs. My gripe is how quick the checker works. If I want to modify the MTU on a 5K pair with back to back VPC then I need out of band access to the switch, which most do not have because it seems to make more sense to uplink 5K pairs direct instead of through an out of band management network considering they are copper. It's so quick that even the multi-send technique of secureCRT does not work. At least give me 10 seconds!!!!

The consistency checker makes anyone fear god to make even the smallest changes without standing right in front of the 7K or the 5K. Who, still, doesnt get a little scared every time <vlan> scrolls the buffer every time you create one?

I went ahead and spent quite a bit of money on console servers, which i really never felt i needed in the past for access switches, because of consistency checker.</vlan>

comments.html:
Having spent the last week or so playing with our new Nexii (?) before they go live we had the same issues with inconsistencies when applying new config to vPC'd ports.

One thing that we have used is the CFS service to keep both sides in sync at all times, the main reason that we were using it was to keep the FEX configs all the same (we dual-home them) but I suppose it could be used for other uses such as Po's.
